title: New Connection command not in default menu location
author: Ben-Conrad
body_snippet:
I upgraded from 1.72.x to 1.75.7012.16814 and now I find it much more difficult to connect to servers due to the 'New Connection' menu item being relocated to the middle of the menu.  

Normally I'm pasting server names in very easily because the New Connection command is right at the top of the menu.  Is there a way to re-order this back to the original?

<!-- Bug -->
|Detail|Value|
|--:|---|
|Operating system | Windows 2012 R2 |
|mRemoteNG version| 1.75.7012.16814  |

iterations.description: The report is stale and unverified on current builds, and fresh reproducible steps/evidence are required before implementation.
The 'New Connection' command is missing from the main File menu, where users expect to find it alongside 'New Connection File'.

The 'New Connection' command is currently located near the bottom of the connection tree context menu, deviating from standard UI conventions where creation actions are typically prioritized at the top.

notes:
AI triage (codex): The report is stale and unverified on current builds, and fresh reproducible steps/evidence are required before implementation.
Approach: Retest on v1.79.x with exact steps plus expected/actual behavior and screenshots/logs, then implement menu-placement and new-connection focus fixes if reproduced.
AI triage (gemini): The 'New Connection' command is missing from the main File menu, where users expect to find it alongside 'New Connection File'.
Approach: Add a 'New Connection' menu item to FileMenu.cs using Language.NewConnection, referencing the active ConnectionTreeWindow to trigger the add connection logic.
AI triage (gemini): The 'New Connection' command is currently located near the bottom of the connection tree context menu, deviating from standard UI conventions where creation actions are typically prioritized at the top.
Approach: Move `_cMenTreeAddConnection` and `_cMenTreeAddFolder` to the top of the `Items.AddRange` list in `ConnectionContextMenu.cs` to improve discoverability and adherence to standard UI patterns.
